bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Frank F. Law, March 16, 1948

div1.p: Hench thanks Law for providing the inserts of Cornwell's painting for the Hall of Fame celebration. He says the Mayo Foundation has 600 fellows - rather than the normal 350 fellows - due to men returning from the war, and thus fellowships are very competitive.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Frank F. Law, March 16, 1948
div1.opener:
March 16, 1948
Mr. Frank Law
Wyeth Incorporated
1600 Arch Street
Philadelphia, Pennsylvania
My dear Mr. Law:
div1.p:
It was extremely kind of you and your colleagues to make available
for the program of the Hall of Fame the colored inserts of the painting
“Conquerors of Yellow Fever”. I hesitated to involve you in this but I could
think of no finer time or place for dignified publicity than a Hall of Fame
celebration. I know Miss Lyons was delighted with your cooperation.

Now, as to another matter. As you may know, the Fourth International
Congress on Tropical Medicine is being held in Washington the week of May 10
to 18. On the evening of May 12, they are having a Walter Reed celebration
or memorial event. I am giving the “principal oration”. The Surgeon General
is to be master of ceremonies I believe, etc. etc. My talk will be illustrated
and an always, I use a slide of Cornwell's painting. I have just received word
from Dr. Wilbur A. Sawyer, the general chairman of the Program Committee, and
from Colonel Raymond O. Dart of the Army Institute of Pathology, that they wish
to set up a Walter Reed exhibit to be displayed during the Congress. Apparently
another exhibit will concern Sir Ronald Ross, a conqueror of malaria and certain
English physicians are bringing material for that exhibit. I have suggested to
Colonel Dart that a reproduction of Cornwell's painting should certainly be on
exhibit. I do not want to commit you to exhibit the original painting but you
might like to consider that. They are making extensive plans for quite a large
international congress and the Cornwell painting would have the great advantage
of mentioning not only Reed but also Finlay, thus pleasing the Latin Americans.
You may be hearing from Colonel Dart.

As to your young friend, Dr. Thomas Noone, I shall look up the situa-
tion here in the Foundation. It has been very difficult. Before the war, we
had about 350 fellows but during the war 250 fellows left before completing
their fellowships and 340 other men who had received appointments for fellow-
ships entered the military service before getting here. The Foundation con-
sidered that it had a moral obligation to these 600 men and held the fellow-
ships open for them. Most of them have returned and to accommodate them,
practically no new fellowships have been given here for two years. We now
have about 600 fellows. They are hanging from the rafters. The situation
will adjust itself within the next year or 18 months but during that time
it will be still quite difficult to get a fellowship here, in any subject.
You may be surprised to know that recently the number of applications for
fellowships here actually equalled half the number of all graduates of all
medical schools in the country. Because of the excessive number of applica-
Mr. Frank Law
- 2 -
March 16, 1948
tions, the Foundation has been able to set up very high standards and only
accepts the top men from the various medical schools. Knowing only little
about Doctor Noone's record, I could not say whether he would have any chance
for the small number of fellowships that might be available in 1948 and 1949,
but I shall discuss your letter with the Director of the Mayo Foundation and
drop you a note shortly.

If I can give Doctor Noone any encouragement it will be well for
him to at least send for an application and when it is properly filled in and
his references returned, it will be well for him to visit here, making
certain that the Director and other members of the Fellowship Committee are
to be in town when he arrives. I should be glad to take him personally
to the Foundation Office and introduce him around.
div1.closer:
Always sincerely, P. S. Hench, M. D. PSH:alc
P. S.: Have you ever published Doctor Fitz excellent talk given at the
unveiling of the Oliver Wendell Holmes painting? I don't think I ever saw
Fred Rankin's paper. They are both excellent and I do hope they will be
published.
